body_html:
Yeah the paper "Use of Extended Euclidean Algorithm in Solving a System of Linear Diophantine Equations with Bounded Variables" pretty much summarises what I've been thinking of, except it corrects a mistake in my quick analysis that made the algorithm to appear to be linear in d instead of exponential 😕

Considering this, I think that if we want to handle those cases, then we should implement a few heuristics and forget about solving the general equations (just always fall back to a warning). It's both expensive and hard to implement (due to integer overflows).

body:
Yeah the paper "Use of Extended Euclidean Algorithm in Solving a System of Linear Diophantine Equations with Bounded Variables" pretty much summarises what I've been thinking of, except it corrects a mistake in my quick analysis that made the algorithm to appear to be linear in `d` instead of exponential 😕

Considering this, I think that if we want to handle those cases, then we should implement a few heuristics and forget about solving the general equations (just always fall back to a warning). It's both expensive and hard to implement (due to integer overflows).
